metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Descendant of Harnarain Singh

facts.text: Under a treaty between the East India Company and Nawab Asafuddaula, the Province of Banaras was ceded about the year 1775 to the East India Company.
The Company granted a sanad to Raja Chet Singh, conferring rights and powers previously held by him afresh.
Raja Chet Singh granted in jagir pargana Syudpore Bhettree in perpetuity to his Diwan Ousan Singh as remuneration for services.
East India Company confirmed the grant made by Raja Chet Singh to Ousan Singh.
Raja Chet Singh succeeded by Raja Mahip Narain Singh who executed a sanad affirming the grant to Ousan Singh.
Land revenue settlements made in Province of Banaras about 1789-90, but jagirs including Syudpore Bhettree excluded.
Ousan Singh died in or about 1800, succeeded by son Sheo Narain Singh.
In enquiry by Collector of Ghazipore under Regulation 11 of 1819, declared grant to Ousan Singh for life only, not heritable or transferable.
Collector's decision confirmed by Commissioner of Bihar and Banaras, subject to recommendation that Sheo Narain Singh maintained in possession for life.
Government in 1828 directed detailed settlement with village zamindars, offered Sheo Narain Singh allowance for life of one-half of revenue assessed.
Sheo Narain Singh declined offer and commenced action in civil court contesting validity of resumption order.
Government resolved in July 1830 to revise resumption order, ordered Sheo Narain Singh considered Tahsildar of parganas Syudpore Bhettree, office hereditary so long as conditions not infringed.
Sheo Narain Singh died before resolution communicated, succeeded by son Harnarain Singh who withdrew suit and signed compromise incorporating terms.

On August 19, 1831, Secretary to Government requested preparation of sanad granting parganas on istimrar tenure to Harnarain Singh and heirs in perpetuity on condition of paying 3/4ths of Jamma, with provisions for proprietary claims, Tahsildar office hereditary, 1/4th deduction for separated villages.
Harnarain Singh refused to accept sanad and Tahsildar office on those terms.

Proceedings for settlement commenced; on November 16, 1832, Settlement Officer reported summary settlement: 166 mahals with zamindars (revenue Rs. 1,28,196), 12 mahals with jagirdar (gross Rs. 22,840, reduced to Rs. 17,130).
Board of Revenue suggested Harnarain Singh receive 1/4th of net collections after deducting Tahsil expenses (Rs. 36,322-8-), recommended sanad conferring pension in perpetuity.
Letter dated September 13, 1837: Lt. Governor suggested remission of 1/4th on 12 mahals (Jamma Rs. 17,130), pension of 1/4th net collections on 166 mahals (Rs. 30,612-8-0).
Letter dated October 19, 1837: Lt. Governor adopted Board's recommendation, allowance Rs. 30,612-8-0 out of net Jamma Rs. 1,28,960; remission on 12 mahals.

Letter dated September 14, 1838: Government intended clear fourth of net revenue as pension to Muqurrureedar; arrangement for remission on certain mauzas for convenience; Muqurrureedar owner during life, responsibility for Jumma.
Formal sanad contemplated but never issued; allowance paid through Treasury since 1838 to Harnarain Singh and descendants, called malikana, pension or share in revenue.
In 1951, U.P. Legislature enacted Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act 1 of 1951; revenue authorities stopped payment relying on s.6(b).
Respondent (descendant of Harnarain Singh) filed Writ Petition No. 464 of 1954 in Allahabad High Court for mandamus to continue payment of allowance/malikana/pension.

High Court judgment dated March 6, 1956: rejected preliminary objections, held right not an estate, not acquired, no compensation needed; predecessors granted allowance in lieu of abandoning land revenue rights.

legal_issues.text: Whether the right of the respondent to receive the allowance under the arrangement of 1838 was extinguished as a consequence of vesting of Syudpore Bhettree parganas in the State under s.4 of U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951, particularly under s.6(b).

petitioner_arguments.text: The allowance is an estate or right/privilege in respect of land or land revenue under s.6(b), liable to determination; respondent was proprietor in 12 mahals which vested; entire allowance affected.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: U.P. Zamindari Abolition Act s.3(8), s.4, s.6(b); U.P. Land Revenue Act s.32, s.78

respondent_arguments.text: Right to receive pension/allowance/malikana not an estate; no nexus to zamindari system; not land, immovable property or estate; no compensation contemplated; third party contract right unaffected.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: U.P. Zamindari Abolition Act s.4, s.6; no provision for such compensation in ss.37-45

court_reasoning.text: Allowance not an estate under s.3(8) as not area in registers; first part of s.6(b) inapplicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right to Rs.30,612-8-0 not interest in land or revenue of 166 mahals; granted as consideration for relinquishing jagir rights; measured by 1/4th net revenue but not a right in respect thereof.

court_reasoning.text: For 12 mahals, respondent proprietor; remission of revenue was right in respect of land revenue which determined under s.6(b); cannot convert to positive payment post-vesting.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Difference of Rs.5710 was remission; right vested in State.

court_reasoning.text: s.6(b) extinguishes grants/confirmations of title to land or rights/privileges in respect of land/land revenue; allowance not such, as consideration for settlement of claim; no compensation provision supports non-extinguishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preamble aims to abolish intermediaries' rights in estates; respondent not intermediary qua allowance; s.45 machinery not extending acquisition.

holdings.text: High Court right in holding allowance of Rs.30,612-8-0 (for 166 mahals) not extinguished by s.6(b); but wrong for Rs.5710 remission on 12 mahals, which determined.

statutes_cited.name: Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined estate, vesting, consequences including extinguishment of grants/rights in land/revenue; compensation assessment; applied to hold partial extinguishment

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Land Revenue Act, 1901
statutes_cited.relevance: Registers for estate definition; assignees of land revenue; no application to pargana

statutes_cited.name: Regulation 11 of 1819
statutes_cited.relevance: Enquiry into proprietary rights; held grant for life only

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed in part; High Court order modified: petition dismissed insofar as remission of land revenue on 12 mahals (Rs.5710 approx.); confirmed for allowance of Rs.30,612-8-0 as pension not extinguished.
outcome.relief_granted: Mandamus for payment of Rs.30,612-8-0 annually; no relief for 12 mahals remission.

key_quotes.text: "the allowance was not in respect of land or its revenue it was granted as consideration for settlement of a claim litigated in a civil court relating to that land."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes allowance from right in land/revenue under s.6(b)

key_quotes.text: "Absence of a provision in the Act for payment of compensation for a right such as the one claimed by the respondent strongly supports the plea that the right is not intended to be acquired or extinguished."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets legislative intent; supports non-extinguishment of pension

key_quotes.text: "what the Government intended to give is a clear fourth of the net revenue of the Pargana to the Muqurrureedar as pension."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes 1838 letter characterizing allowance as pension
